document.docAuthor: Asenstorfer, Robert E. & Ryder, Maarten H. & Jones, Graham P.
document.docTitle: Agrocinopine C, a Ti-plasmid-coded enzyme-product, is a 2-O, 6-O linked phosphodiester of D-Glucose and sucrose

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Agrocinopine C, a Ti-plasmid-coded enzyme-product, is a 2-O, 6-O linked phosphodiester of D-Glucose and sucrose

paragraph.docTitle: Agrocinopine C, a Ti-plasmid-coded enzyme-product, is a 2-O, 6-O linked phosphodiester of D-Glucose and sucrose

paragraph.docAuthor: Robert E. Asenstorfer, Maarten H. Ryder

paragraph.emphasis: School of Agriculture , Food and Wine, University of Adelaide, Waite Research Institute , PMB 1, Glen Osmond , South Australia , 5064, Australia

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Ti plasmid
Plant biochemistry
Sugar transport
Crown gall
Agrocinopine
Sucrose phospho-diester
Permease induction
Acyclic aldehyde-anomers
A B S T R A C T

Agrocinopine C is a small molecule found in crown gall tumours induced by pathogenic
Agrobacterium radiobacter
carrying the tumour-inducing plasmid pTi Bo542. This phosphodiester opine was isolated (at 0.02 g / 100 g fresh wt.) from sunflower (
Helianthus annuus
L.) galls. It is structurally related to agrocinopine A and is a glucose-2- phosphodiester linked to the C6-hydroxy-methyl group of the glucose moiety of sucrose. Sugar-2-phosphates are uncommon in plant tissues, whether transformed by
Agrobacterium
or not. 1 H and 31 P NMR signal multiplicity indicates five-fold anomeric complexity of agrocinopine C in solution, implying that the permeases taking up these sucrose-phosphodiesters could recognise any one of the five anomers. Data suggests that the open chain aldehyde forms of the 2-phosphorylated opines agrocinopine C and agrocinopine A and the corresponding phosphorylated glucose-2-phosphoramidate component of the antibiotic agrocin 84 play a central role in agrocin’ s selective toxicity to certain strains of
Agrobacterium
after uptake via Ti plasmid-encoded permeases.

Formulation of the “opine” concept ( Guyon et al., 1980 ) made the fundamental connection between a particular agrobacterial Ti plasmid and the genes encoded on the T-DNA portion that is inserted into the plant genome. Most of the known opines such as octopine, nopaline, leucinopine, mannopine etc. are secondary amines, formed by the reductive conjugation of either the carbonyl of an α- keto acid (or a reducing sugar aldehyde) condensation product with the α- amino group of an L-amino acid. They were isolated individually from tumours incited by various pathogenic strains of
Agrobacterium radiobacter (Beijerinck and van Delden) Conn
Rhizobiaceae (formerly
A. tumefaciens (Smith and Townsend) Conn
). Thus the “opine” concept led to the realisation that by “engineering” the plant’ s metabolic activities, the bacterium forces the plant to provide nitrogen in a form that only the bacterium can catabolise. Considerations by Ellis and Murphy (1981) predicted and confirmed that other opines must exist in plant tumours and two different carbohydrate phospho-diesters, agrocinopine A and agrocinopine C, were discovered, each one providing both a phosphorus source and an energy source (carbohydrate) for the tumour-inciting bacteria. The complete structure of agrocinopine A was published by Ryder et al. (1984) and an Honours degree project on agrocinopine C was submitted by the late Anna E. Savage (A.E.S.; Savage, 1983 ). The discovery of
Agrobacterium
-derived T-DNA genes in the genomes of all 291 cultivated sweet potato accessions tested, including a gene showing significant similarity to a Ti-plasmid encoded agrocinopine synthase gene ( acs ; Kyndt et al., 2015 ) prompted us to re-examine A.E.S’ s original 1983 agrocinopine C sample using current mass spectrometry and NMR techniques and facilities.

Recent work has provided insight into the close link between the active uptake of agrocinopines into tumour inducing strains of
Agrobacterium
, via specific transporters, and the “Trojan horse” uptake of the structurally-related, naturally occurring fraudulent adenine-dinucleotide bacteriocin, agrocin 84 ( Chopra et al., 2013 ; Murphy et al., 1981 ; Tate et al., 1979 ). Agrocin 84 is produced by
Rhizobium rhizogenes (Riker et al.) Young et al.
Rhizobiaceae (formerly
Agrobacterium
biovar 2) strain K84 and its derivative strain K1026 ( Tate et al., 1979 ) and belongs to an emerging class of antibiotics termed amino acyl tRNA inhibitors ( Chopra et al., 2013 ; Pang et al., 2021 ; Travin et al., 2021). The production of agrocin 84 by
R. rhizogenes
strain K1026 also plays a vital role in the commercial biological control of the economically important crown gall disease of plants including stone fruits and roses ( Kerr, 2016 ).

We now report the structure of agrocinopine C which is related to, but nevertheless somewhat different from the sucrose phosphodiester structure of agrocinopine A ( Ryder et al., 1984 ). Agrocinopine A is a phospho-diester of sucrose linked from the C4-hydroxyl of the fructo-furanosyl moiety to the C2-hydroxyl of L-arabinose. Agrocinopine B is also a phosphodiester and was obtained from agrocinopine A by acid cleavage of the glucose moiety from the sucrose moiety. The original agrocinopine A structure ( Ryder et al., 1984 ) was initially disputed by Messens et al. (1985) but later confirmed by Messens et al. (1986), albeit with two mis-attribution errors in key references. In the same context, it should be noted that although agrocinopines each contain three sugar moieties, only the two in sucrose are linked by a glycosidic bond and consequently the agrocinopines A and C should not be referred to as tri-saccharides. Ultimately, the original structure ( Ryder et al., 1984 ) for the L-arabinosyl-phosphodiester of sucrose was unequivocally confirmed by synthesis and shown to be identical in all respects with the natural product agrocinopine A by Franzkowiak and Thiem (1987) and Lindberg and Norberg (1988) , including its biological activity.
☆ This paper is dedicated to the memory of Anna E. Savage (dec’ d 1997) and Max E. Tate (dec’ d 2016) and is based on their and Maarten Ryder’ s initial studies. * Corresponding author.
E-mail address: maarten.ryder@adelaide.edu.au (M.H. Ryder).

The purpose of the current paper is to provide evidence for the structure of agrocinopine C present in plant tumours incited by pathogenic
A. radiobacter
which carry the Ti-plasmid pTiBo542, and to emphasise the hitherto unrecognised complexity of the anomeric equilibria for solutions of agrocinopines A and C in addition to the corresponding anomeric complexity in solutions of the structurally-related, naturally occurring fraudulent adenine-dinucleotide bacteriocin, agrocin 84.

The agrocinopine C negative ion (M-H) gave an observed mass 583.1275 m /z ( Fig. 1 ), the calculated mass for the M-H formula: C 18 H 32 O 19 P is 583.1281. The ionisation pattern, m/z (relative intensity; ion), gave 583.1275 (b.p.; M-H + ) - , 421.0740 (0.37; M-H + -glucose) - , 353.2107 (0.09; M-H + -229.9168) - , 283.2625 (0.13; M-H + -229.8650) - , 255.2318 (0.25; M-H + -327.8957) - , 112.9852 (0.54; H 2 PO 5 ) - , 96.9602 (0.13; H 2 PO 4 ) - . The ion at m/z 421.0740 indicated a loss of glucose, peaks at 353.21, 283.26 and 255.23 m /z suggested fragmentation of the remaining sucrose-phosphate moiety, while the peak 96.6 m /z was consistent with dihydrogen phosphate.

IR (diffuse reflectance; Fig. 2 ): ν = 3402 (OH, stretch), 2929 ( CH 2 asymmetric vibration), 2863 ( CH 2 symmetric vibration), 1623 (OH deformation, 1412 ( CH bending), 1353 (P––O), 1101 (OH–P––O), 1035 (C–O, C–C vibration), 847 ( CH deformation), 812 ( CH deformation), 683, 618 ( CH 2 ), 592 cm 1 .

Fig. 3 shows the characteristically linear pH mobility profiles for the phosphodiesters agrocinopines C and D and a two-step dissociation profile for the ribose 5-phosphate monoester control. The biological activity of agrocinopine C following electrophoretic separation and further purification steps was detected in the plate bioassay (Fig. 4) developed by Ellis and Murphy (1981) .

Total phosphorus estimated by the method of Bartlett (1959) gave 0.64 μMoles/mg. Total hexose estimated by the phenol-sulphuric acid method ( Dubois et al., 1951 ) yielded 1.96 μMoles/mg, and the total D-glucose determined by the glucose oxidase assay gave 1.2 μMoles/mg. These data provided mole ratios of 1:3.06:1.87, i.e. integer values approximating to 1:3:2.

Ammonolysis products (1.5 M NH 4 OH/110 ◦ C/40min, sealed tube) separated by electrophoresis at pH 1.7 (formic/acetic buffer) yielded neutral sugars ( RmOG 0.0), unresolved D-glucose mono-phosphates ( RmOG 0.61) and inorganic phosphate ( RmOG 0.53).

Ammonium borate (0.2 M) electrophoresis (pH 9.2) of the ammonolysis neutral sugar (pH 1.7) fraction showed the presence of glucose ( RmOG 0.91) and sucrose ( RmOG 0.09). Electrophoretic separation of the glucose phosphates ex ammonolysis indicated the presence of unresolved cyclic glucose 1,2- and 2,3-phosphates ( RmOG 0.81), glucose 1- phosphate ( RmOG 0.97), glucose 2-phosphate ( RmOG 1.11) and glucose 3-phosphate ( RmOG 1.27). Alkaline phosphatase (E.C. 3.1.3.1) treatment (32 ◦ C/2 h) converted all glucose phosphates to D-glucose ( RmOG 0.83) and inorganic phosphate. Treatment of the glucose (32 ◦ C/1 h) with glucose oxidase (E.C. 1.1.3.4) smoothly converted it quantitatively to Dgluconate ( RmOG 1.07).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. High resolution mass spectrum of agrocinopine C.

Fig. 2. Diffuse reflectance mid infra-red spectrum of agrocinopine C. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)
Fig. 3. Relative electrophoretic mobilities ( RmDNBS ) of ribose-5-P (triangle; pKa 1 =1.32, pKa 2 =6.58), agrocinopine C (circle) and agrocinopine D (square) between pH 1.7 and 10.

subSection.paragraph: Addition of a slight excess of sodium borohydride (NaBH 4 , 0.6 mol per mole of aqueous agrocinopine C) produced a compound ( RmOG 0.55, pH 1.7) that was no longer positive to the p -anisidine reagent for reducing sugars ( Hough et al., 1950 ). Ammonolysis (1.5 M NH 4 OH) followed by alkaline phosphatase (EC 3.1.3.1) treatment yielded a non-reducing polyol ( RmOG 0.94; 0.2 M ammonium borate buffer pH 9.2), which was indistinguishable from D-glucitol ( RmOG 0.94). Electrophoresis of this polyol in a lanthanum trinitrate buffer (0.2 M in 0.75 M formic acid/1 M acetic acid) produced a cationic (lanthanum-complex) polyol spot ( RmOG 0.71) indistinguishable from a reference sample of D-glucitol ( RmOG 0.71).

Brief acid hydrolysis (1 M acetic acid/15min/110 ◦ C) produced 4 distinct components (A, B, C and D), when examined by paper electrophoresis at pH 1.7 ( Savage, 1983 ). Component A ( RmOG 0.57) had the same relative mobility and biological activity as agrocinopine D and also no longer reacted positively to the ketose sugar reagent of urea/phosphoric acid ( Avela et al., 1977 ). The remaining components, B, C, D, were not formally identified.

At the time of the original isolation (by A.E.S, 1983) the complexity of the isomeric proton NMR data due to the available instrumentation was not interpreted, nevertheless the greater resolution of the proton decoupled 13 C NMR data provided good support for the proposed structure for agrocinopine C based around the observed degradation data ( Savage, 1983 ). Recent 13 C NMR data obtained using the HSQC protocol agreed well with the data collected in 1983 and has permitted detailed and improved assignments ( Table 1 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 4. Bioassay detection of agrocinopine C. The left plate shows detection of agrocinopine C in the pH 1.7, anionic paper electrophoretogram segment marked C, by its induction of antibiotic activity in the normally insensitive K478 (syn. A281) overlay, from a source of agrocin 84 produced by the chloroformsterilised, colony of
R. rhizogenes
strain K84 grown at the centre of both plates. The radius of the normal toxic concentration range of agrocin 84 extends approximately to the location of the paper squares. The right plate demonstrates that glucose 2-phosphate (square A) induces no detectable sensitivity to agrocin 84, glucose 6-phosphate (square B) no detectable sensitivity and purified agrocinopine C (C) induces a very strong uptake of the antibiotic. It is noteworthy that unlike agrocinopine A, which extends the inhibition zone perimeter ( Ellis and Murphy, 1981 ; Ryder et al., 1984 ) beyond the squares, agrocinopine C only induces sensitivity inwards towards the original agrocin 84 producer colony.

subSection.paragraph: Proton NMR (estimated purity 76.2%) exhibited ten methylene signals ( 4.070 –3.324 ppm), four methine ( 3.519 –3.704 ppm) and major signals for two anomeric protons 5.269 ppm and 5.271 ppm, glucose-2- phosphate and the glucose unit of sucrose respectively ( Table 1 , Figs. S1–S 3 ). The glucose-2-phosphate anomeric proton had four signals indicating the presence of the α- pyranosyl, β- pyranosyl, α- furanosyl and β- furanosyl anomers ( Table 2 ). Two signals observed in the HSQC ( Fig. S4 ) for glucose-2-phosphate g5 proton, 3.706 ppm and 3.714 ppm, confirm the presence of the pyranosyl and furanosyl anomers. Similarly, two pairs of signals observed for the g2 and g3 protons were associated with the pyranosyl and furanosyl anomers.

Coupling constants of the methylene glucose protons g2 (pyrano, 4.066 ppm/furano, 4.070 ppm) and g3 (3.928 ppm) were 8.9 Hz, 8.5 Hz, respectively. Both shifts and coupling constants were clearly influenced by the presence of phosphate when compared with the 1 H NMR of glucose (MestReNova, 2014). The non-phosphorylated glucose g2 proton had a shift of 3.233 ppm (double-doublet) while the g3 had shift of 3.728 which was not resolved from the g6 protons. The glucose unit of sucrose methylene proton sg5 (3.441 ppm) had three coupling constants (j =0.9, 3.9, 10.0 Hz) consistent with coupling with the sg6 protons as well as long range coupling with the phosphate. Coupling constants of the methine protons sg6 (3.995 ppm) (dd; j =3.3; 5.5 Hz) also indicated coupling with the phosphate. Expected doublets for the anomeric protons g1 and sg1 (5.269 ppm and 5.271 ppm) were not resolved.

The initial carbon spectrum, obtained by Tate and Savage (1983) indicated carbons sg6c (63.5 ppm, 2 Jpoc 3.06) g3, (77.55 ppm 3 Jpocc 6.1), g2c (82.0, 2 Jpoc 1.88) and g1 (98.1, 3 Jpocc 0.87) were coupled with the phosphate. Subsequent two-dimensional NMR agrees with the initial carbon assignments except that sf1 and sf6 are reversed ( Figs. S4 and S 5 ). There was satisfactory agreement of 13 C NMR with literature data for sucrose ( Wishart et al., 2009 ), glucose 2-phosphate ( DePaoli-Roach et al., 2015 ) and the Mnova Prediction Software (MestReNova, 2014).

caption.paragraph: 13 C and 1 H NMR data for agrocinopine C (including two-dimensional NMR data).

subSection.paragraph: Protons at 4.070 ppm (j =8.9 Hz) and 3.995 ppm (j = 3.3, 5.0 Hz) were coupled with phosphate. The 31 P NMR (estimated purity 85.4%) indicates the presence of both pyranosyl (3.241 ppm) and furanosyl anomers (2.80 ppm) with no splitting of the individual anomers ( Fig. 5 ). The aldehyde/gemdiol, which cannot be differentiated, can be observed at 4.029 ppm. 1 H – 31 P gHMBC confirmed that only these three phosphate signals were associated with agrocinopine C ( Fig. S6 ). These three signals collapsed into a single peak when the glucose-2- phosphate was reduced by sodium borohydride to give glucitol-2- phosphate (1.55 ppm) which only has a single anomer ( Fig. 5 ).

The high-resolution mass spectrum for the agrocinopine C sample provided an elemental M-H anion composition (C 18 H 32 O 19 P) which corresponds to that for a phospho-diester linking sucrose to a hexose instead of the pentose (L-arabinose) observed for agrocinopine A ( Ryder et al., 1984 ). An erroneous preliminary structure for agrocinopine C based on an in vitro synthesis was reported by Lindberg and Oscarson (1993) and subsequently in a review by Clare (1995) , and this must be corrected. In agrocinopine C, D-glucose-2-phosphate is linked to the 6-hydroxymethyl carbon of the glucopyranosyl moiety of sucrose ( Fig. 6 ) and consequently it is the fructosyl moiety which is lost by brief acid hydrolysis of the labile sucrose C1α- linkage of glucose to C2α- fructose to yield agrocinopine D. In contrast, agrocinopine A has L-arabinose-2-phosphate linked to the C4-hydroxyl of the fructo-furanosyl moiety of sucrose and it is glucose that is lost by brief acid hydrolysis (yielding agrocinopine B).

tableNote.paragraph: d NOESY coupling between Hsg2 and Hsf1.
e HMBC 31 P, phosphate at 2.80 ppm is coupled to protons at 4.070 ppm and 3.996 ppm.

caption.paragraph: Table 2 Concentration of anomeric forms determined by 31 P and 1 H NMR data for agrocinopine C Angyal and Pickles (1972) ; O’ Connor et al. (1979) and Kaufmann et al. (2018) .

Fig. 5. (a) 31 P NMR signals for agrocinopine C, α/β pyranosyl anomers (-2.80 ppm), α/β furanosyl anomers (-3.24 ppm) and the aldehyde anomer and/or its hydrate (-4.03 ppm). No evidence for a detectable amount of the hydrated aldehyde as a separate 6th signal was observed in these 31 P NMR observations. Peaks at -3.09 and -3.12 ppm are not correlated to any agrocinopine C protons by 31 P gHMBC. (b) Agrocinopine C 31 P NMR signals collapse to a singlet after borohydride reduction (-1.55 ppm).

Fig. 6. Structural relationships for agrocinopine C and its various anomeric equilibria. The presence of the aldehyde anomer and/or its hydrate and α/β pyranosyl and α/β furanosyl anomers is consistent with the three signals detected in the 31 P NMR and five anomeric proton signals observed in the 1 H NMR (Table 2, Table S1). (ChemBioDraw, 2014).

subSection.paragraph: It is remarkable that two quite different Ti plasmids (the Bo542 agropine and the T37 nopaline plasmid) contain biosynthetic genes on their T-DNAs for two related phospho-diesters of sucrose. The close structural relationship of the glucose-2-phosphoramidate motif of agrocin 84 (Fig. S7) to the glucose-2-phosphodiester of agrocinopine C is evident.

Ellis and Murphy (1981) provided clear 32 P evidence for enhanced uptake of agrocin 84 by the nopaline strain
R. rhizogenes
K57A, after pre-incubation for 4 h with agrocinopine A. In the absence of pre-incubation, agrocinopine A also completely blocked the normal uptake of agrocin 84 by the pathogen K57A, thereby demonstrating that they both entered the cell by the same uptake mechanism. By contrast with the nopaline strain K57A, there was no uptake of agrocin 84 whatsoever in the absence of agrocinopine C by the agropine strain A281. However, pre-incubation of strain A281 for 6 h with a similar concentration of agrocinopine C allowed subsequent uptake of agrocin 84, leading to the toxic effect seen in Fig. 4 . It is apparent that the transport system for uptake of agrocinopine C is normally repressed but is induced when this opine is present. The tumour-inducing plasmid pTiBo542 contains an operon which is homologous to the acc operon of the agrocinopine A-encoding plasmid pTiC58 ( Oger et al., 2001 ; Wetzel et al., 2015 ). The acc operon of pTiC58 codes for an ABC-type uptake system (genes accA to accE ) and for catabolism of agrocinopine A via genes accF and accG ( Kim et al., 2008 ). It is evident that the acc operon of pTiBo542 encodes similar functions that enable the uptake and catabolism of agrocinopine C as well as the uptake of agrocin 84. The repressors coded for by the accR genes on pTiC58 and pTiBo542 function differently in that the acc operon on pTi58 (agrocinopine A) is normally partially expressed, whereas it is not expressed on pTiBo542 until agrocinopine C is present. This accounts for the difference between Fig. 4 and Ryder et al. (1984) in agrocin 84/agrocinopine bioassay result, an effect first reported by Ellis and Murphy (1981) .

Wurster and Hess (1974) emphasise a point originally made by Los et al. (1956) that “cyclic configurations are equilibrated via the open chain configurations, aldehydes and ketones respectively”. The possibility that acyclic forms such as the aldehyde or its hydrate might be present in significant amounts in some equilibria has not been addressed in previous studies ( Ryder et al., 1984 ; Messens et al., 1986; Lim and Seib, 1993 ). Nevertheless, the presence of aldehydic proton signals in the 1 H NMR leave little doubt that aldehydic species contribute significantly to anomeric mixtures of sugars phosphorylated at the 2- or 6- position for the reducing sugars examined in this study.

Swenson and Barker (1971) detected < 0.4% of the aldehyde of D-glucose-6-phosphate in aqueous solution. Allowing for the difference in methodologies, in this study we observed a similar value for the aldehyde (0.6%) in the 31 P NMR data for glucose-6-phosphate ( Table S1 ). Because of its enhanced resolving power, 31 P NMR signal multiplicity data appears to be a useful method to detect the presence of anomeric acyclic aldehyde and or aldehyde hydrate forms in reducing sugar phosphate solutions. However, in order to prevent 31 P interpretation problems due to complexity associated with anomeric solution equilibria ( Angyal and Pickles, 1972 ; Angyal, 1991 ) we suggest three approaches:

Firstly, examine whether the 31 P signal multiplicity is increased by slowing down the rate of anomerisation, by lowering the temperature as, for example, in the case of L-arabinose-2-phosphate (Fig. S8).
Secondly, observe whether borohydride reduction of the acyclic carbonyl collapses the phosphorylated reducing sugar 31 P multiplet to a polyol-phosphate singlet ( Fig. 5 , Fig. S8).
Thirdly, two-dimensional NMR, 1 H– 31 P HMBC provides information regarding the correlation between closely linked protons and phosphate atoms ( Fig. S6 ).

Sodium borohydride reduction of glucose-2-phosphate to a glucitol–phosphoryl moiety in agrocinopine C removed its effect in the agrocin 84/
A. radiobacter
strain K478 bioassay. Similarly, sodium borohydride reduction of agrocinopine A converted the arabinose 2- phosphoryl moiety to the corresponding L-arabinitol 2-phosphoryl moiety and this molecule no longer enhanced the diameter of the inhibition zone in an agrocin 84 bioassay overlaid with the nopaline/agrocinopine A type pathogenic
A. radiobacter
strain A208 ( Ryder et al., 1984 ). The simplest explanation for this loss of biological activity of the agrocinopines after reduction of the aldehyde to the polyol, is that the carbonyl of the acyclic aldehyde group plays a pivotal role in binding the reducing sugar moieties to the respective periplasmic binding proteins responsible for their uptake by the pathogen. Transient condensation of the carbonyl group of the acyclic aldehyde anomers of reducing sugar species, with an α- amino group of a binding protein or the free amino group of a membrane lipid as for example phosphatidyl ethanolamine or phosphatidyl serine to form a lipophilic-complex with a weak (-C-OH. NH-) bond, enables transport into the cell. Imine formation, such as this, is favoured at pH 5 which is close to physiological pH. The toxic agrocin 84 enters the cell using the same mechanism (Fig. S7). Once inside the cell, with subsequent hydration in a different pH environment, the transiently bound phosphorylated reducing sugar is released, thereby achieving transport across a very hydrophobic lipid bilayer.

Two non-pathogenic
R. rhizogenes
strains, K84 and its derivative K1026, have provided world-wide protection against the plant cancer known as crown gall caused by pathogenic strains of
Agrobacterium
on stone fruits and roses for more than four decades. Agrocin 84 production by these strains, and the uptake of this “pro-toxin” by crown gall-inciting
Agrobacterium
and
Rhizobium
is critically important to the success of biological control. On the basis of X-ray crystal structures of the periplasmic binding protein AccA, coded for by the nopaline Ti C58 plasmid, and affinity studies, El Sahili et al. (2015) concluded that the importation of agrocin 84 and agrocinopine A both require a pyranose-2-phosphate moiety. We also are in agreement with the necessity for a reducing sugar 2-phosphate for Ti plasmid-coded entry of the agrocinopines and agrocin 84 into the target bacterium. However, because of the loss of biological activity after reduction ( Los et al., 1956 ) we are not convinced that the data provided by these authors has proven beyond doubt that the most important motif is the pyranoside species and not an alternative component of the rapidly equilibrating anomeric mixture, especially the acyclic linear aldehyde and/or hydrate.

The essential basis for the control of crown gall pathogens by
R. rhizogenes
strains K84 and K1026 ( Kerr, 2016 ) is due to the entry of agrocin 84 via the same transport mechanism as agrocinopines A and C which act as nutrients for pathogen growth.

Agrobacterium radiobacter
(formerly
A. tumefaciens
) strain K478, a strain which produces agrocinopine C in its tumours, is also the agrocin 84 overlay strain for detection of agrocinopine C. Strain K478 contains the pTi Bo542 plasmid from the agropine tumour-inducing strain Bo542 and is synonymous with strain A281 (Sciaky et al., 1978), which does not catabolise either octopine or nopaline. Strain K84 the producer strain for agrocin 84 is deposited with NCPPB in the UK . The agrocinopine C producer strain
A. radiobacter
A281 (Syn K478) was generously provided by Dr Mary-Dell Chilton (University of Washington , Seattle, Washington , USA ).

Electrophoretically homogeneous agrocinopine C was isolated from tumours induced by the pathogenic
Agrobacterium radiobacter
strain K478 as follows. Crude agrocinopine C was obtained from crown gall tissue ( 312 g ), harvested from wounded sunflower-stems that had been previously inoculated with
A. radiobacter
strain K478. The macerated gall tissue was homogenised in 70% v/v ethanol and centrifuged (Sorvall RC-5B at 2310× g for 15 min). The supernatant was collected and combined with three 70% ethanol washes of the pellet. The ethanol was removed by rotary evaporation in vacuo , and residual water insoluble material was removed by filtration through Whatman 541 filter paper. The crude aqueous extract was loaded onto a 500 mL bed of Dowex 1X-2 Anion exchange resin ( 100 g , 25 mm × 300 mm ) in the acetate form, washed with water 2.5 L, and eluted with a volatile acetate buffer (pyridine 0.2 M/acetic acid 0.1 M), ~pH 5, and 10 mL fractions were collected. Biologically active fractions (10 μL subsamples) were detected using Whatman No 1 filter paper squares placed around a centrally located 36 h-old patch culture of
R. rhizogenes
strain K84 on Petri plates of Stonier’ s medium ( Stonier, 1960 ) as producer of agrocin 84 to provide a source of this adenine nucleotide antibiotic ( Fig. 4 ). The squares with aliquots of the agrocinopine C ion-exchange eluate fractions were placed on the agar which was then overlaid with the normally insensitive strain K478 and plates were incubated at 27 ◦ C for 2–3 d. Active eluate fractions (100–240) induced agrocin 84 inhibition zones as shown ( Fig. 4 ). Buffer was removed from the bulk sample by evaporation in vacuo at 30 ◦ C to yield a semisolid residue ( 590 mg ), yield 0.19% of the fresh tumour weight. This active residue was dissolved in distilled water (300 mL), loaded onto a 500 mL bed of Dowex 1X- 2 in the bicarbonate form, washed with water (2 L) and eluted into fractions (10 mL) with a linear gradient (0–0.2 M) of NH 4 HCO 3 at pH 9.2. Biologically active material eluted in fractions 130–180 (0.05–0.1 M NH 4 HCO 3 ), in vacuo concentration at 30 ◦ C yielded a dry residue ( 340 mg , 0.11%) of the ammonium salt. This crude agrocinopine C was then eluted with water through a 50 mL Dowex 50 column in the lanthanum form. The un-retained, biologically active, agrocinopine C component eluted in fractions 2, 3 and 4 and was found to be AgNO 3 /NaOEt reagent ( Trevelyan et al., 1950 ) glycol-positive, molybdate reagent phosphate-positive ( Harrap, 1960 ), urea/phosphoric acid reagent ( Avela et al., 1977 ) ketose-positive, p -anisidine reagent ( Hough et al., 1950 ) hexose-positive. Its electrophoretic mobility ( RmOG ) at pH 1.7 was 0.43, and yield was 158 mg (0.05%). Repetitive preparative electrophoresis in the volatile formic acetic buffer (pH 1.7) with subsequent elution, neutralisation with ammonia and drying, yielded 57.3 mg (0.02%) of electrophoretically homogeneous agrocinopine C.

The mid-infrared spectrum was obtained using Spectrum One Fourier Transform Infra-Red (FTIR) spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, Massachusetts , USA ) using a diffuse reflectance attachment (Pike Technologies, Madison, Wisconsin , USA . Approximately 10 mg of agrocinopine C was mixed with about 90 mg potassium chloride and loaded into the measurement cell.

Mass spectra were obtained using a high resolution electrospray mass spectrometer (MicroTOF-Q, Bruker Daltonics Corporation, USA ) operated in negative ion mode for analysis. Capillary voltage was set at 3500 V with an end plate offset potential of 500 V. Data were collected from 50 to 1500 m /z with an acquisition rate of 1 s. Dry gas was set to 6 L min 1 at 200 ◦ C with a nebulization gas pressure of 2.0 bar. Samples were introduced by direct infusion.

Original 13 C NMR spectra were recorded ( 17.5 mg in 0.5 mL D 2 O) on a JEOL FX-90Q spectrometer. Subsequent 1 H, 31 P and two-dimensional ( 2 mg in 0.6 mL 20% D 2 O) NMR data were obtained using a Varian Inova-600 spectrometer. For comparison, data was obtained for glucose-6-phosphate (Sigma Aldrich), glucose-1-phosphate (Sigma Aldrich) and arabinose-2-phosphate (synthesised by Ryder, 1984 according to the method of Sarfati et al., 1977 ) all at a similar concentration of 2 mg in 0.6 mL 20% D 2 O. The 31 P NMR was measured relative to H 3 PO 4 .
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

The authors thank Prof Allen Kerr for helpful discussions. A.E.S was the recipient of the R.K. Morton and J.R. Barker scholarships. M.E.T. has funded the completion of this work via the University of Adelaide Alumni Society. NMR data was obtained originally for A.E.S. on a Jeol FX90Q instrument by G.P.J. More recent data was obtained by Phil Clements on a Varian 600 MHz instrument at the University of Adelaide, North Terrace Campus. High resolution MS data was obtained by Jeremy Hack on a Bruker-Daltronics micrOTOF-Q instrument at Metabolomics Australia located within the Australian Wine Research Institute, Urrbrae, South Australia .
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.113013.
